questions.text: Regarding infanticide, feticide, and filicide in India, which of the following statement is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Infanticide is punishable by death or imprisonment for life

options.label: B
options.text: Feticide is the killing of a fetus at any time prior to birth

options.label: C
options.text: The killing of a living child in the mother’s womb who has not yet breathed cannot be considered infanticide

options.label: D
options.text: Female feticide is the act of aborting a fetus because it is female

questions.correct_answer: C. The killing of a living child in the mother’s womb who has not yet breathed cannot be considered infanticide
questions.explanation:
Term

Definition

Legal Aspects

Infanticide

Killing of an infant at any time from birth up to the age of 12 months
  • Charged under Section (Option A)
  • Punishable by death or imprisonment for life and fine

Feticide (Option B)

Killing of the fetus at any time prior to birth
  • Causing the death of a quick unborn child amounts to culpable homicide
  • Applies even if the child is killed in the womb and may not have breathed or been completely born (Culpable homicide- Sec.92 BNS)
  • Punished with imprisonment up to 7 years and/or fine if with woman’s consent.(Sec.88 BNS)
  • If without the woman’s consent up to 10 years with or without a fine. (Sec 89 BNS)

Female Feticide (Option D)

Act of aborting a fetus because it is female

Covered under laws against feticide and sex determination

Neonaticide

Killing of a child within 24 hrs

  

Filicide

The deliberate act of killing a child by the parents

Treated as murder under Section 103 BNS

questions.text: A stillborn fetus is discovered during a routine prenatal checkup. The fetus shows skin slippage on the face and back, soft and flaccid tissues, and a sweetish disagreeable smell, but no gas formation. The skull shows mild cranial compression but no overlapping of cranial sutures. Based on these findings, approximately how long ago did fetal death likely occur?
questions.explanation:
Time Since Death

Maceration changes observed

12 hours

Earliest sign: Skin slippage of face, back, or abdomen

24 hours

Skin becomes brown or purplish in color

> 36 hours

Cranial compression becomes visible

72 hours (3 days)

Desquamation over 75% of body surface

> 96 hours (4 days)

Overlapping of cranial sutures

> 1 week

Mouth is widely open

Throughout process
  • Fetus is soft and flaccid
  • Sweetish disagreeable smell
  • No gas formation
  • Internal organs show autolytic decomposition (except lungs and uterus)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with suspected intrauterine fetal death at 36 weeks gestation. Which of the following findings would be LEAST useful in confirming recent fetal demise?

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of skin slippage on the fetus's face and back

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of fetal heart sounds on electronic fetal monitoring

questions.explanation:
Sign

Imaging Modality

Description

Timeline

Absence of Fetal Heart Motion (Option D)

Ultrasound

No detectable cardiac activity on real-time imaging

Immediate indicator of fetal death-

Absence of Fetal Movements

Ultrasound


 

No spontaneous or induced fetal movements during examination

Immediate indicator of fetal death

Robert's Sign

(Option C)

 

Ultrasound

Gas bubbles in fetal heart chambers and great vessels

May appear by 12 hours, but can be difficult to interpret

Hyperflexion of Spine

 

X-ray, Ultrasound

Abnormal curvature of the fetal spine due to loss of muscle tone

Variable, typically seen in later stages

Spalding's Sign (Option A)

Ultrasound

Overlapping of fetal skull bones due to loss of brain tissue consistency

Appears about 7 days after fetal death

Loss of Rib Parallelism

X-ray

Ribs lose their normal parallel arrangement and overlap present

Later sign, associated with collapse of thoracic cavity

Deuel’s Halo Sign

X-ray

Indicates elevation of the subcutaneous fat layer from the underlying bone caused by edema

Not reliable sign, as can be seen in both living and dead fetus

questions.text: Match the following tests with their correct descriptions: 1. Wreden's test a. Compares the weight of lungs to body weight ratio before and after respiration 2. Ploucquet's test b. Checks for air bubbles in the stomach and intestines 3. Fodere's test (Static test) c. Examines the presence of air in the middle ear 4. Breslau's Second Life test d. Observes the weight change of lungs after respiration
questions.explanation:
Test Name

Description

Key Points

Wreden's test

Examines the presence of air in the middle ear

- Absence of gelatinous embryonic connective tissue

- Presence of air in the middle ear after live birth

Ploucquet's test

Compares the weight of lungs to body weight ratio before and after respiration

- Ratio before respiration: 1/70 of body weight

- Ratio after respiration: 1/35 of body weight

- Demonstrates establishment of respiration

Fodere's test (Static test)

Observes the weight change of lungs after respiration

- Weight becomes approximately double after respiration due to increase in blood flow to lung beds after breathing

- Not constant due to factors like edema, pneumonitis, or amniotic fluid inhalation

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is examining the lungs of a newborn during an autopsy. The lungs appear mottled in color and occupy most of the thoracic cavity. However, when subjected to the hydrostatic test, portions of the lung tissue sink while others float. Microscopically, some areas show expanded alveoli lined with flat squamous cells, while other areas show closed alveoli lined with cuboidal cells. What is the most likely explanation for these conflicting findings?

options.label: A
options.text: The infant was stillborn, and the floating lung portions are due to putrefaction

options.label: B
options.text: The infant was live-born but suffered from severe respiratory distress syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: The infant was live-born and partially breathed before death

options.label: D
options.text: The findings are inconclusive and could be due to artificial respiration attempts

questions.correct_answer: C. The infant was live-born and partially breathed before death
questions.explanation:
Feature

Unrespired Lung (Stillborn)

Respired Lung (Live-born)

Color

Bluish red

Mottled

Volume

Small

Large, covers heart

Thoracic cavity

Not full

Fully occupied

Pleura

Loose, wrinkled

Taut, stretched

Margins

Sharp

Rounded

Surface

Smooth

Uneven

Consistency

Dense, firm, non-crepitant (liver-like)

Soft, spongy, elastic, crepitant

Ploucquet's test

1:70

1:35

Fodere's static test

30–40 g

60–70 g

Diaphragm level

4th–5th rib

6th–7th rib

Blood oozing

Little, frothless

Abundant, frothy

Hydrostatic test

Whole and parts sink in water

Floats in water

Alveoli

Not expanded

Expanded

Microscopy

Closed sacs with cuboidal/columnar lining

Dilated sacs with flat squamous lining and vascularity

questions.text: A forensic examiner is evaluating two fetuses found under different circumstances. The examiner performs Breslau’s First Life Test on Baby A and Breslau’s Second Life Test on Baby B. The findings are as follows: For Baby A, after performing the hydrostatic test, the lungs sink when compressed and placed back in water. For Baby B, air bubbles are observed escaping from the stomach and intestines after an incision is made underwater. What do these findings suggest about the live birth status of both babies?

options.label: A
options.text: Baby A was stillborn, while Baby B was born alive and breathed.

options.label: B
options.text: Baby A was born alive and breathed, while Baby B was stillborn.

options.label: C
options.text: Both Baby A and Baby B were born alive and breathed.

options.label: D
options.text: Both tests are inconclusive due to potential contamination.

questions.correct_answer: A. Baby A was stillborn, while Baby B was born alive and breathed.

questions.text: A newborn is examined shortly after delivery. The physician observes a localized swelling on the baby’s head that appears several hours after birth. The swelling is confined to one side of the skull, is firm to the touch, and does not cross the suture lines. What is the most likely diagnosis for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

 Cephalohematoma

Caput Succedaneum (Option A)

Definition

Blood collection between the periosteum and skull due to a ruptured emissary vein, often from trauma (e.g., forceps delivery).

Swelling from fluid accumulation between scalp layers, typically from prolonged pressure (e.g., during labor).

Situation

Generally unilateral, commonly over the parietal bone.

Can be bilateral, covering a broader area of the scalp.

Impulse on Crying

(Seen in hydrocephalus)

No impulse seen.

No impulse seen.

Limitation by Suture Line

Confined by sutures.

No restriction by sutures.

Underlying Pathology

May involve a skull fracture.

Non-pathological; usually harmless.

Occurrence

Does not appear at birth, and usually develops later.

Present at birth.

Development and Disappearance

Appears 12–24 hours after birth, and resolves in 6–8 weeks. Maybe followed by jaundice.

Disappears on its own within 24 hours. Maybe followed by jaundice.

Medico-Legal Importance

Can assist in determining how long the infant survived post-birth based on regression.

Provides clear evidence of in-utero life, though, in prolonged labor, fetal death may occur before birth.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is found unresponsive in their crib by a caregiver early in the morning. The infant had been healthy and fed well the previous evening. The caregiver reports the baby typically sleeps on their stomach. An autopsy is performed, revealing no conclusive cause of death. Which of the following statements is most accurate based on the scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Sleeping on the stomach significantly reduces the risk of death.

options.label: B
options.text: The autopsy typically reveals specific pathological findings.

options.label: C
options.text: Low birth weight or premature infants have an increased risk of sudden death.

options.label: D
options.text: Maternal smoking has no post-natal association with infant mortality.

questions.correct_answer: C. Low birth weight or premature infants have an increased risk of sudden death.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is frequently admitted with gastrointestinal distress, including vomiting and abdominal pain. The mother provides elaborate details about the symptoms and insists on multiple tests despite negative results. Symptoms appear only when the mother is present, and the child seems healthy when separated. What is the most likely diagnosis for the child’s condition?

A 2-year-old girl presents with persistent crying, refusal to eat, and multiple bruises. The parents report frequent falls. On exam, there are bruises on the abdomen and back, a healing burn on the thigh, and rib tenderness. X-ray done is shown below. The parents give vague explanations and claim the child "bruises easily." A CT scan reveals subdural hematoma without a clear trauma history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
